G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 212, §3, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $25,000.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 212, §3, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $25,000.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover her actual damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, as well as reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the security of the building’s entrance constitutes an “indirect interference” with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, §14.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.support_reasoning: The case does hold that the landlord’s conduct in allowing recurrent flooding constituted an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. However, the interference here stems from failure to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions inside the premises, not from failure to maintain building entrance security. The opinion nowhere discusses building entrance security or characterizes such a failure as an ‘indirect interference,’ so it cannot be cited as authority for that specific proposition.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.relevant_excerpt: As its third objection to Solomon’s recovery on her count for interference with quiet enjoyment, Gem asserts that it was wrongly held responsible for the actions of third parties beyond its control. … The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. … The jury found in answer to a special question … that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The Defendant’s inaction permitted repeated unauthorized entry into the building, mail theft, and other disturbances that deprived Plaintiff of the peace, comfort, and security contemplated by the tenancy.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The proposition is that the landlord’s inaction, allowing repeated unauthorized entry and related disturbances, deprived the tenant of the peace, comfort, and security contemplated by the tenancy. Doe squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to take available measures to remove unwelcome persons engaged in unlawful activity, where their presence seriously interferes with tenants’ use of the property, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. That directly supports using landlord inaction in the face of such disturbances as a basis for liability for loss of peace, comfort, and security in the tenancy.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment…. If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment "protects the tenant from serious interference with her tenancy."
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion directly characterizes the failure to provide heat as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment because it seriously impairs the character and value of the premises. This aligns with the proposition that the covenant protects the tenant from serious interference with her tenancy, and the court’s reasoning and citations (e.g., to Winchester v. O’Brien and Brande v. Grace) ground that understanding in Massachusetts law.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself … liability will be imposed ‘whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.proposition: A landlord’s omission to repair known defects that create security or safety risks constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.support_reasoning: The court interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 to require at least negligent conduct and expressly identifies a landlord’s failure to repair known defects as a common basis for liability under the quiet enjoyment statute. It cites prior cases and states that a landlord’s omission to repair defects of which he has notice, where the natural and probable consequence is interference with the tenant’s rights, violates § 14. That aligns with the proposition that not repairing known safety or security risks can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 749 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: A landlord’s omission to repair known defects that create security or safety risks constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment but does not state or imply that a landlord’s omission to repair known security or safety defects necessarily constitutes a breach. Instead, it reiterates the general standard that quiet enjoyment protects against serious interference and usually requires landlord notice and at least negligence, then holds there was no breach because the landlord acted promptly and the conditions were remedied. The case therefore does not establish the specific rule that failure to repair known safety or security defects is itself a breach; it actually finds no breach on the facts presented.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850-851 (1997). Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions… The trial judge did not err in…[finding no] breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.proposition: The Defendant’s actions and omissions were willful, knowing, and undertaken with reckless disregard for Plaintiff’s rights.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.support_reasoning: The case concerns constructive eviction and breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, not willful or reckless misconduct. The court expressly notes that the landlords did not intend to create the harmful conditions and focuses on their conduct and ability to control the noise, not on a mental state of willfulness, knowing violation, or reckless disregard of tenants’ rights. Thus it does not provide authority for the proposition that defendants’ actions were willful, knowing, or reckless.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.relevant_excerpt: “The judge further found that, although the landlords did not intend to create the conditions, the landlords ‘had it within their control to correct the conditions which... amounted to a constructive eviction of each [tenant].’… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871 (.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also constitutes an unfair and deceptive act under the principles articulated in Simon v. Solomon, supra, and Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871 (1991), though Plaintiff limits her claim here to G.L. c. 186, §14.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871 (.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Haddad for the idea that the conduct at issue can constitute an unfair and deceptive act, even though the plaintiff is choosing to limit her remedy to G.L. c. 186, § 14. In Haddad, the SJC expressly holds that the landlord’s abusive, harassing, and retaliatory conduct toward a tenant—including conduct supporting intentional infliction of emotional distress—constituted unfair and deceptive trade practices actionable under G.L. c. 93A, and it affirms a substantial Chapter 93A award on that basis. That directly supports using Haddad as authority that similar landlord conduct is an unfair and deceptive act, even if the plaintiff elects to proceed only under c. 186, § 14.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871 (.relevant_excerpt: On the G.L.c. 93A counterclaim, the judge found that Gonzalez had suffered two discrete injuries as a consequence of Haddad's unfair and deceptive trade practices: emotional distress, and the diminution in value of the apartment due to Haddad's breach of the warranty of habitability. … we conclude that, in appropriate circumstances, tenants may recover multiple damages for the intentional infliction of emotional distress under c. 93A. … [T]he judge was justified in concluding that Gonzalez had made out a common law case of intentional infliction of emotional distress. Compare Simon v. Solomon…
